awd_titl_txt: FET: Small: A Portable and Intelligent Testing System for Power-efficient and Accurate Foodborne Pathogen Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
Foodborne illness is a common, distressing, and even life-threatening problem for millions of people around the world. Food testing is becoming a common need for our daily lives, i.e., a sensitive and cost-effective detector can guarantee the safety and quality of food to fulfill strict food legislation and consumer demands. However, current electrochemical sensors not only require lengthy and complex sample processing, but also need expensive equipment for an adequate level of purification and enrichment. Meanwhile, low-cost sensors produce noisy signals that require computationally expensive machine-learning models for noise-robust processing. To remedy these issues, this research project is to develop an intelligent food-pathogen detection system, which is portable and affordable, yet accurate. The success of this project will enable affordable, portable and accurate food-borne pathogen detection, including food analysis, food safety, food-borne illness detection and therapy, water measurement, and many microbiome-related environmental monitoring. This project will provide an intellectual foundation for portable, disposable, intelligent foodborne pathogen detection expanding the burgeoning biosensor, machine learning and hardware accelerator design research community.

Specifically, this project aims to develop (1) a portable electrochemical sensing system detecting foodborne pathogens in contaminated foods, (2) hardware-friendly bitwise machine learning models for de-noising and recognition of real-samples and (3) an ultra-low power and portable accelerator for bit-wise machine learning inferences. The three aims are to improve the recognition performance in a collaborative fashion, where affordable sensing technology is backed up by machine-learning-based signal processing, while the hardware-algorithm co-design controls system-level efficiency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project is composed of three tasks: (1) a portable electrochemical instrument; (2) hardware-friendly machine learning models for denoising; and (3) an ultra-low-power and portable PIM accelerator for machine learning inferences.

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts:

The research contributions in this proposal address unique sensor, algorithm, and hardware challenges of constructing a portable foodborne pathogen detection system with support for a disposable electrochemical sensor, bitwise machine learning models for noise denoising and recognition of real-samples and a PIM accelerator for bitwise machine learning inferences. This proposal is a key step toward making foodborne pathogen affordable, portable, power-efficient, and more accurate for critical domains such as food safety, food poisoning detection and water measurement. The improvement in portability, disposability and affordability stemming from the contributions of this proposal enables power-efficient and accurate foodborne pathogen detection applications from food analysis in developing countries to water contamination detection. In a broader sense, the proposed robust and hardware-friendly sensing system can also contribute to other application domains such as environmental sensing using IoT devices, drones, and robots, that are with multimodal sensors, but are not tightly synchronized. As there are applications that need device-wise decision making due to the harsh environmental constraints, the fundamentals studied in this research can be applicable to the other domains, too. To broadly disseminate results, the PIs published papers in top academic journals and conferences in design automation, machine learning and biosensor design. Publishing the outcomes of this project makes the broader research community aware of the concepts and challenges of building a foodborne pathogen testing system. 

Outcomes: 

 1. Hongwei Cai, Zheng Ao, Chunhui Tian, Zhuhao Wu, Connor Kaurich, Zi Chen, Mingxia Gu, Andrea G. Hohmann, Ken Mackie, Feng Guo, "Engineering human spinal microphysiological systems to model opioid-induced tolerance," Bioactive Materials, 2022, 

2. Sunwoo Kim, Haici Yang, and Minje Kim, ?Boosted Locality Sensitive Hashing: Discriminative Binary Codes for Source Separation,? in Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing (ICASSP), 2020.

3. Sunwoo Kim and Minje Kim, ?BLOOM-Net: Blockwise Optimization for Masking Networks Toward Scalable and Efficient Speech Enhancement,? in Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal Processing (ICASSP), 2022.

4. Sunwoo Kim and Minje Kim, ?Boosted Locality Sensitive Hashing: Discriminative, Efficient, and Scalable Binary Codes for Source Separation,? IEEE/ACM Transactions on Audio, Speech, and Language Processing, vol. 30, pp. 2659-2672, Aug. 2022.

5. Qian Lou, Sarath Chandra Janga, and Lei Jiang. "Helix: Algorithm/Architecture Co-design for Accelerating Nanopore Genome Base-calling," In Proceedings of the ACM International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques, New York, NY, USA, 293?304. 

In addition, we open-sourced all our projects in the public Githup repository as follows:

1. https://github.com/kimsunwiub/BLSH

2. https://github.com/kimsunwiub/BLSH-TASLP

3. https://github.com/kimsunwiub/BLOOM-Net

 

Significant Results: 

First, for the electrochemical sensor, we propose bacterial sensing using an acoustically enhanced electrochemical sensor. We anticipated the detection of bacterial cells (E.coli) using our fabricated AEOT sensor (a manuscript in preparation). We employed our new developed sensors for measuring bacterial cells (E.coli) with a concentration range (from 100 million cfu/ml to 0). We found that our AEOT sensor significantly improved the detection level of bacteria by ~100 times compared to conventional organic transistors. Moreover, we also showed our AEOT sensor can reduce incubation time by 80% at this sample time. This acoustic sample enrichment device is simple, versatile, and can be early coupled to various chemical bonding-based sensors such as chemical sensors, electrical sensors, and optical sensors. 

Second, for the hardware-friendly machine learning model, we created a data-driven hashing for pattern recognition in the binary space. We have focused on compressing this kind of machine learning model by using one-bit quantization, or binarization. Our effort in this area is different from the common approach to this binarization problem. Typically, binarization or low-bit quantization begins with a fully-trained big model, whose model architecture is already defined and fixed. Hence, quantization is to reduce the bit-depth of the model parameters and data stream with a minimal performance loss. On the contrary, our approach was to completely re-design the topology, so the model architecture can flexibly grow as it needs more accurate results (or reduce if it needs to save the resources). 

Third, for the hardware accelerators for machine learning inferences, we proposed an analog-to-digital converter (ADC)-free PIM. State-of-the-art PIM accelerators take advantage of analog computing to maximize inference throughput of quantized neural networks, but the functioning of their analog computing style heavily depends on a large number of CMOS ADCs that significantly increase their power consumption and area overhead. For instance, CMOS ADCs cost 58% of power consumption and 30% of chip area in a typical PIM design. We created a 3D Spin Orbit Torque MRAM (SOT-MRAM)-based array architecture to accelerate analog-to-digital conversion operations without CMOS ADCs.

Modified by: Lei Jiang
